reviewText:
Ok so this game is quirky, it is fun, and it is definitely different. It is an A-RPG at it's core, with a story, albeit short at the moment. I do recommend you give this game a shot, if you had fun with other ARPG's, even Binding of Isaac fans could really get into this, altough it has more in terms of items, and managing things. I guess I will do the standard Pros and Cons for people here. . .

Pros:
1:  Game has fun old-school style graphics (I enjoy at least, not everyone's cup of tea I understand though)
2:  You control a starship and crew, with mechs to help you in battle if you choose
3:  Action-RPG that rewards skill, as opposed to just rewarding grinding as many turned based RPG's do (This is not  turned based obviously being an ARPG
4:  Many upgrades for yourself, and upgrades for your mechs
5:  You can board enemy ships, to take them as your own, or buy a better ship if you want instead
6:  You can choose to play as a fighter or a commander, either going in and leveling while killing, or letting mechs do the   work and staying in the back
7:  The price of this game is very low, and IMHO you will get your money's worth of hours of fun
8:  Walking around areas, using the action key, you find genetic material or download data or find parts to upgrade mechs all space stations and stuff. Stuff that looks like part of the scenery, actually holds value, which I find endearing. It doesn't stick out, and scream COME GET ME." You have to use your brain on this one folks.

Cons:
1:  There are some bugs

reviewText: While the actual gameplay seems like it could be fairly decent, it is ruined by the god-awful user experience. Every single part of the UI is as bare bones as you can get, no polish whatsoever, and chalk full of bugs. Even simple things like fullscreen vs. windowed mode is pretty broken. For example, when you die in windowed mode, the game goes back to fullscreen mode until you change it again. Also, in less than an hour of play time, I've experienced 3 crashes due to some mouse script the game is running. And why on Earth is the game always on top" of other windows?!\n\nHopefully the dev will one day see that user experience is extremely important and fix all the issues and polish the UI
date: as the game really might be something worth playing. Until then
hoursPlayed: it is very difficult to reccomend this game... to anyone."

reviewText:
So this game could be a lost gem in the retro gaming world but due to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ programming it's not.
The game is actually really fun, you travel around space, beat some aliens and other opponents, completing various missions, buy new spaceships ect. ect. it could be a very fun game if there was no darkside.

The darkside of the game is that the programming is really bad and here is why:
- The mouse programming ( which is absolutly not needed in this game) keeps the game crashing over and over again. Till you Figured out that keeping the mous on the middle of the screen solves the problem.
- THe resolution options of the game dont work properly. If you change the resolution the screen gets of center so you cant see things like health or shield
- Sometimes for no reason you cant board spacestations or planets. The game keeps you on your ship and you can try it over and over again with no chance to broad anything
- Sometimes the game gets stuck in a loop of spaceshipfights. That actually happend only once and leaded me to glitch the hell out of the game. Because everytime you try to scan a space object a fight with an enemyspaceship breaksout. In my case the enemy was a puny little ship that didn't match mine in any aspect, so it took me no time to defeat it foor about 50 times, but you got always new loot from it. After that i got bored and made some missions and broke the stuck loop.

So if there is any update wich would fix the problems above than it will be a gem in retro gaming but actually its not.

reviewText: This is certainly an addictive little game, you are the captain of your spaceship in a space universe that reminds me of the oldschool sci-fi videogames/movies. It's got a starwars-spacesim feeling to it while being an oldschool sandbox rpg. There are missions you can do such as bounty hunting, collector missions, missions for earth government such as destroying enemies. You can walk inside your spaceship at any time and equip your own character with armour and different weapons. You can even throw grenades while battling. You can also beam down with your mechs and they help you, but the low-tech mechs are stupid and bump into walls a lot while better mechs are more efficient. There are many items to find and collect and use for stuff like improving your mechs.  Loving the game and surprised by its depht i'm taking a small break then playing all night. That's why i don't have many hours of playtime but i will play it a lot and do bounty hunter missions, they're my favorite :)

reviewText:
The game would not even start, complaining that a minimum screen resolution of 1366x768 is required.  For now I'm stuck with a 4:3 monitor at 1280x1024 resolution.  By sheer dumb luck I noticed a file named 1366w.txt in the game directory which led me to this thread:

https://steamcommunity.com/app/363510/discussions/0/537405286658273077/

With that I was able to get the game running in 1280x720 resolution and play for some time.  Not really the most user friendly thing, and really should be fixed by making a small loader program to make this change for you then run the game.

Beyond that, the game is okay from what I've seen so far.  A little buggy and with the usual RPG maker interface annoyances.  I'm okay with the price I paid for it as I got it in a bundle.  I can't really recommend it for the full $10 price as it currently stands though.

reviewText:
The last few patches have really improved this game to the point where I now feel I can publicly endorse it.

Certainly there are a few small issues with the control system but overall this game is a little gem! Firstly it is huge! Not only do there seem to be many and varied missions, but there is also an option to fly around random space. I personally prefer this mode as every time you encounter something in space you enter your ship and get to chat with your crew. It feels as though you are a Star-Trek captain J

There also seems to be a really interesting story although I’ve not played it all the way through yet as the missions for it become difficult quickly. This is not a game for those that like to be hand-held but instead makes you work things out for yourself (which I personally like). TBH I’m not even sure how you could explain everything to the user as there is so much going on, so much to buy, and so many ways to play.

Definitely worth a look for such a small cost!

reviewText:
I hate giving bad reviews, especially since the concept itself is interesting for this game, and there seems to be a lot of content that I just haven't gotten to yet.


However, in my very brief time playing, the game has already crashed twice. The look of the game is tacky and appears incomplete, and the game plays very slowly. Even on a high performance machine, I experienced frame drops and the aforementioned crashes; even when the game isn't lagging, it still feels like I'm struggling to execute the controls I want because of the awkward mechanics. I quickly lose desire to play because of how awkward it is to even try.

There are some good ideas I see, but those same ideas are better explored in other games I think.
Not recommended, unless the developers patch it up and smooth out the rough edges pretty soon.

reviewText: I think this game has great potential after the minor bugs and crashes are taken care of. The premise of this RPG is very cool. I'm reminded of the early Final Fantasy games on the SNES. It took me some time to get adjusted to the controls but once I figured it out, it was pretty simple. I used WASD as well as the Up Down Left Right Arrows and the numpad. Enter Esc for buying.\n\nI was actually quite surprised by the amount of material in this game. There were at least four stores and two I have yet to figure out. I'm guessing to craft. Anyways, I'm playing this game at my own pace, which is slow, so there is much more to explore and learn. Overall, I think this game is pretty cool.

reviewText: I enjoyed STAR-BOX very much, it's a fun (yes, there's humour in space!) RPG that lets you choose your adventure in a variety of ships, while traversing the infinite space looking for trouble. It has a retro style that fits very well with the pace of the game. Didn't have any lag/graphical issues by the way.

reviewText:
If you want to help this guy raise his new baby, and be there to hold his hand through his first attempt at making a game, then this game is for you.
If you want a sandbox RPG that gets updated and runs well without a dozen bugs hitting you in the face every 5 minutes, look elsewhere.



The game looks cool, seems like a good idea, but it is my opinion that this developer has little to no experience making games. The game isnt optimized, runs like crap on new systems, the options menu is an abysmal joke, and there are soooooo many bugs, its not worth $10.


If this game goes on sale for $3, it would be worth it.   But it seems that releasing new DLC is more improtant than polishing this jagged rusty hunk o junk.    I wrote this bad review after seeing that he released DLC that has nothing to do with fixing the games jagged edges.

(Note to the Dev)   DLC is for AFTER the game is released, otherwise, it seems like you are just collecting money for a broken game. Pets should be free for having to put up with this hunk o crap. Youd be better off getting Junk Jack on iOS for $.99

reviewText:
Having recently given up on Fortune's Tavern as a hopeless game i tried this one. I wondered long if this one works better and if i should buy it... though i see they both share the same kind of combat engine. Surely this one will work better right?

No. It's terrible. And i have come to the conclusion that this game engine just isn't cut for fun action oriented gameplay. Sure you can get this to work somewhat but the fun part is just missing. Combat on ships is something that i can imagine some people love despite(or because) the sluggish way the characters move giving you a stuttering Archon -like linearity to combat. Fortune's Tavern dejavuu is very strong here.

The biggest sin i think this game engine brings to the table is that it overshadows the story. You are spendng so much time on being annoyed by it that you just dont even care about the story. Yes i understand, some people like it. But i just can't as there really are WORKING action games such as Secret of Magia that does the action part right.

Not going to be spending much ink on the game mechanics itself - i see others have already taken care of that. Instead i am going to just issue a general warning for action games that has this game engine underneath. Now by this i dont mean rpgmaker games generally as  i have recently learn't to like a lot of more traditional rpgmaker games but this particular engine that is used on the more action oriented games is just a general disaster and i will avoid it like the plague in the future.

reviewText:
Star-Box is a sci-fi, sandbox, RPG, made using RPG maker, developed by FlynnFour Games. The game has you focusing on exploring the stars in your ship, allowing you to fly from planet to asteroid to space station, and even get into space-faring battles with other ships.

The game is made in RPG maker, an engine over the years that has had it's fair share of mediocre and lazy titles. But thankfully, I'm happy to report that this is not the case. As instead of using the typical RPG maker assets and combat system, the developer has opted for their own. The in-game assets are nice to look at and fit the overall sci-fi theme well, so if you're looking for an RPG maker game that likes to put in some effort into their games, this is definitely one for you.

The combat isn't turn based like the usual RPG maker games, but instead has gone for a more action-oriented combat style. While exploring the stars, you are more than likely to come across your fair share of combat on different worlds, asteroids, and what not. You'll beam down, and that's where it all begins! You move around the screen like you normally would, but around you is a number of enemies, who will not hesitate to shoot you in the face the first chance they get. Luckily, you also have access to a form of attack, also known as your laser gun. By pressing 1, you fire a shot in whatever direction you may be facing, although sadly you cannot shoot diagonally, something I would quite like to see in a future update maybe. Thankful though, there is no delay between shots, so feel free to hit that fire button as hard as you please, because you can assume the AI of your opponents are doing the exact same!

One upside to the combat, is you don't need to go it alone all the time. Providing where you're going allows, you can bring down a mech with you, or 6 if you managed to get a ship with that number of mech bays. Mech's are AI partners that work pretty similar to your AI opponents, except on the upside that they work for you. Once you've loaded in to the level, these ruthless killers will go out in search for something that is set to do you harm. The mech's are a wonderful addition to the game, as they help you immensely on almost all missions you go on. Your character is pretty squishy from the get go, so allowing your mech's to deal with the brunt of the enemies on each level is a tactic that is well worth using often. Which is actually why I spent the majority of my money upgrading my mech's, just because they are more or less literal killing machines.

Technically, there's a subsidiary to the combat system, which is the ship on ship combat. This isn't nearly as exciting as the regular combat, as the gist of it is just move closer, or further away, depending on how close you are to the enemy ship you use a different weapon, be it lasers, cannons, or missiles. Along with those attacks, you have tactics, like boost shields (restore health), disable their engines so they can no longer move closer or further away from you, disabling their option to flee from you. Then there's beam aboard once they are below 50 shields, allowing you to go onto their ships and take it out using yourself and the mech's, allowing you to take over and control the ship, something I haven't yet been able to achieve, as the bugger's block me every single time I've tried to do it!!

The game has a rather light-hearted take on itself, which you soon find out when you first try and upgrade your mech's, as your crew-mate says, You may have noticed the AI is pretty bad

reviewText:
Star-Box is a fantastic RPG Space Adventure with a good storyline and rich, detailed graphics.

The game has a retro vibe to it, with strong roleplaying elements to back it up. The controls are exactly as you'd expect from this type of game - simple and easy to master. The tutorial is super-useful too, and not just a rushed-out tutorial like some games, it has its own script!

Playing it for a good length of time, I can easily recommend this game 10/10! :)

reviewText:
My first impression for the game is pretty positive. STAR-BOX is a game you can sit down and play for a few minutes or longer if you're looking to kill some time. The first time I played I easily put an hour into it. I only had some minor issues; nothing that would be considered a deal-breaker (for me).

Issues I had:
-All sounds cut out on the second level of a ship I boarded. (Sounds came back once I moved onto the third level).
-Lasers wouldn't fire when I pressed 1. Tested a couple more times and lasers still wouldn't fire.
-Laser randomly fired (ended up hitting my mech).
-Game slowed down and encountered some delays when opening menus (inventory, etc). This problem occured on the same level I lost all sounds. Once I moved on to the next level, the game returned to it's normal speed(s).

Other than those small issues, I would recommend this game.

reviewText:
Likes:
- The ambition and scope - it's pretty flexible, and there's on-ship, in-space and on-planet.
- Does something not really explored for many years - a bit of FTL, a bit of Star Control, a bit of Sun Dog Legacy, a bit of Star Command

Dislikes:
- The interface is woefully inconsistent (on some screens WASD, on some screens arrows, on some screens mouse)
- Oh, and slow. Where you'd like a table perhaps you get a scrolling list of options in a speech bubble.
- It's buggy and inconsistent (which is more a limit of cramming something ambitious into the RPGmaker XP engine)

Overall:
- I rather like it, despite its shonky nature (that's the Star Command influence at work)
- With a better engine and more polish it could concentrate on the bits it does well, and let the engine handle the interface.

reviewText:
STAR-BOX: RPG Adventures in Space is simply a Action RPG with quirky graphics, nice music and just awkward controls.


When you first jump into the game you can tell it's made with RPG Maker. Gameplay for the most part is great. You run around and loot things with your mech buddy/buddies to improve things like your armor/clothes, your mechs and other things, Flying the space ship is a bit confusing at first because you have no sense of movement because the background doesn't move with your ship. The story in this game is amazing too.

- Crashes do occur, but the dev is ontop of things to fix them and push out patches.

In the end, I do recommend 10/10 because of the hardworking developer, quirky graphics and awesome gameplay. Well worth the $10
voteText: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game, Star-Box, is an easy game for anyone to jump into.  Controls are easy, once you figure them out.  The sandbox elements of this game are really fun, more fun than other sandbox games.  There is a lot to do in the game as well, you can spend a while looting and whatnot.  The most recent update has fixed some of the issue that others were complaining about. I recommend this game for anyone looking for a fun sandbox game, or just looking for something different!

reviewText: Love the game so far, plenty of ambience, loot variety and an explorers dream. reviewText:
It's been quite a fun little game for the price so far.

The controls are a bit awkward, but nothing you can't fix with joy2key and a controller.

Good points:
* Theme is interesting.
* It gives you lots of freedom as well as a goal.
* Ships have different purposes and there are big tradeoffs (escape pod or no?)

Bad points:
* Controls are weird, can only see them when you press ESC and that leaves out the buttons for the grenades (which are listed on the grenade itself, to be fair).
* Hard to hit 1-4 to fire lasers while using WASD, so you'll have to do arrow keys + 1-4 or use joy2key to map buttons to a controller (remember to map the arrow keys directly, do NOT map WASD instead, it won't work).

reviewText: Let's just start by saying I am a Network Systems admin, and a pretty decent programmer and general techie. I bought this game yesterday. The programming on the game is absolutely horrible. The game itself seems pretty fun and a great idea but it is almost completely unplayable in its current state. The frame rate is ridiculously slow, similar to remote accessing a PC with slow internet connection, and things like opening doors or your inventory with freeze the game for several seconds. Some menu options are impossible to select due to the lag. I wanted to like it but I couldn't deal with the programming issues. Because of this I sent first refund request. I have seen that the devs have kept pretty constant updates so far so in the future this might be fixed and I might change my mind and review.  I disagree with the windowed name of Star-bored, I think it could be fun, only if it wasn't Star-broken.

reviewText:
This game feels like a first attempt at making a game by someone who has no experience making a game before. It's slow, difficult to play, and It's riddled with bugs. The dialogue comes off as being juvenile in nature, so it's difficult to get into from that perspective as well. I wasn't able to play the game past the first hour or so; I found a bug that kept giving me reputation and once I hit 30k or so I somehow ended up walking around in space outside my ship with nowhere to go. At that point, I called it quits and requested a refund.

A few examples of what I'm talking about:

http://i.imgur.com/wbpgZWx.png
http://i.imgur.com/55tdVzf.png

There are plenty of other games made with RPG Maker out there that are worth checking out, if that's your fancy, and I don't even know why anyone is calling this game a roguelike.

Don't get me wrong, I think it's great that people are excited about making games and such, but this really should have been a private and free release on the dev's website as a hobby and not something commercially sold through Steam. And for ten bucks? You're out of your mind.

reviewText:
=/

The smily above is my face while playing the game.

I bought Fortunes Tavern a while ago, and had the same expression. I bought both games because im a big fan of the genres and they tend to be my favourite games.

Both games have clunky controls/interface and it's just frustrating to do anything.

Ill concentrate on this game for this review.

Initial tutorial mission, my pet" mech kills all the bad guys. I guess that's ok as it's a tutorial and Im bound to turn into the bad ♥♥♥ eventually. I fire a few shots and realise that as soon as I press fire my character is forced to stop. Why? This is when my burgeoning hopes for the game started to fall.

Tutorial ship to ship combat. Advised I can board a ship if it's below 50 shields. Get ship below 50 shields. Repeated attempts to board are blocked. Figuring If i take out the shields completely I'll do hull damage and have a better chance of boarding. Reduce shields to 0 and ship is gone. Destroyed. Received various items that I don't really have a use for.

Still thinking I can have fun in the game
date: I choose to go to random space rather than earth.\n\nStop at the first asteroid I see
recommended: click on it and get a message telling me it's just a worthless rock. "Fine"
hoursPlayed: I think and try to move on
voteText: but clicking doesn't get rid of the msg (which it had in every other text so far in the game) and space doesn't do anything either. Have to press "o" to go back to ship then click on the ship monitor to go back to exploring space (which took me a few goes too because sometimes the character just walks away from the monitor.)\n\nTried this with a few more asteroids
helpfulPercent: exact same problem.\n\nIgnoring this bug thinking "ok
votesHelpful:
ill just stay away from asteroids" I fly to a new sector of random space. I spot a planet!

Now i think "Yay I can do some exploring and have fun!". Press "Scan sector" from ship. Nothing. I'm directly over the planet. Try it two more times. Nope. Game tells me there's nothing there. It's clearly a giant bogey on the viewing monitor.

Press "o" to go back to ship. Character walks up and down a few times instead of using the monitor. Finally uses monitor. NOW there's a planet there. Oh ok. So the planet only exists if I scan from the ship monitor
votesTotal:
not from space.

That's when I stopped playing.

I forgot to add that I had the exact same error message when trying to load the game initally that I had when trying to load Fortunes Tavern. There's a working fix but... second game and same error?

Anyway I don't want to make the Dev have a bad day. I really want to enjoy your games but the user interface is really killing it for me.

I'd honesly rather have a working turn based environment than the UI currently used. I've never used RPG Maker and I don't know if it's a limitation of the engine.

Dev - great game ideas and you obviously have some talent and strength to make/release games but your UI is stopping me enjoying them."

reviewText:
Lags a bit if you leave it in full screen and needs a load game option for when you blow up that ship you wanted real bad or when you take some random drugs that decrease all your stats.

So far good open world game overall , invade an alien ship with your army of robots that either bump randomly into walls or rain down the fires of destruction on all your enemies. But make sure to equip that robe with +2 defense on it before a dragon shoots a fireball at your head or you pick a fight with an alien warship that seems to ignore your attempts to fight it by flying away as your weak missles bounce off its shields.

Not a bad game for under $10
